justification: The article notes that recent studies investigate context effects by “measuring visual attention using eye-tracking,” explicitly linking the construct of attention to the eye-tracking instrument.

It states that Bhatia (2014) “found that participants had increased memory for features shared by target and decoy options (as measured using a recall task),” directly connecting the memory construct to the recall measure.

The review explains that evidence-accumulation models are evaluated with both choices and “response times,” indicating that response-time data serve as a measurement of the temporal dynamics of decision making.
